H0.text: The fossil record provides evidence that new species develop to fill the habitats where old species lived following a mass extinction.

H1.text: Fossil fuels provide evidence that new species develop to fill the habitats where old species lived following a mass extinction.

H2.text: The erosion record provides evidence that new species develop to fill the habitats where old species lived following a mass extinction.

H3.text: Climate record provides evidence that new species develop to fill the habitats where old species lived following a mass extinction.

A4.text: stromatolite abundance also increased after the end-Ordovician and end-Permian extinctions decimated marine animals, falling back to earlier levels as marine animals recovered.

A5.text: Because of the specialized and rare circumstances required for a biological structure to fossilize, only a small percentage of life-forms can be expected to be represented in discoveries, and each discovery represents only a snapshot of the process of evolution.

A6.text: Subsequent to the P‑T extinction, there was an increase in provincialization, with species occupying smaller ranges – perhaps removing incumbents from niches and setting the stage for an eventual rediversification.

A7.text: Statistical analysis shows that the rock-based abundance estimates can account for only 50% of the observed pattern, and other evidence such as fungal spikes provides reassurance that most widely accepted extinction events are real.
